title: Boy left in agony after pestering mum for a black henna tattoo that burned him
text:
Charlie pestered his mum to let him get a tattoo but it started burning a week later (Picture: Kennedy News)

A boy who begged his mum to let him have an ‘evolution of man’ henna tattoo was left in agony after suffering chemical burnes.

Charlie Gaughan, 11, was on holiday with mum Lisa Gaffney, 34, grandma Carol Gaffney and her boyfriend Mark Byrne in Costa Blanca when he saw the tattoo stall.

Lisa said that he wanted to get the €15 body art showing an ape progressing through to a skateboarder on the last day of the holiday so that he could go swimming.

She said: ‘I said “no” at first and then a friend he met there was having it done so I gave in and he had it done with them.

‘It was a really popular stall, was really busy you don’t think anything’s going to be wrong with it do you?

Charlie Gaughan wanted an ‘evolution of man’ tattoo on his arm, ending with a man on a skateboard (Picture: Kennedy)

A week after he came back from his holiday, the tattoo started itching and burned his skin (Picture: Kennedy)

It took about 10 minutes and initially Charlie was happy, but back at home in Audenshaw, Greater Manchester, a week later it started to irritate him.

The black pigment flaked off and he was left with a chemical burn that became infected.

Lisa said: ‘When I saw I saw the red mark left behind on his arm I panicked. He said it was itchy like mad but also burning him at the same time and couldn’t settle.

‘I felt it was my fault and felt really bad for him because you don’t want them [your child] to be in pain, you just wish you could take that pain from them.’

She was told to take him to A&E in York where he had been staying at his grandmother’s house.

Lisa said: ‘There a doctor bandaged it and said it would need re-dressing and two days later in Manchester we saw a burns doctor who was really good.

Charlie pictured at the henna tattoo stall where he got the artwork on the last day of his holiday (PIcture: Kennedy)

‘He said he didn’t think it would scar and put a special burn cream on it and dressed it again.’

Charlie was given some antibiotics and doctors now hope that because he is young his arms will heal without scarring.

Lisa continued: ‘They said it could take months for it to go fully but there’s always the possibility of it leaving that imprint. It’s looking really good at the minute so I’m hopeful it wont scar.’

She is now urging other parents not to let their children get black henna tattoos.

Lisa said: ‘It didn’t ruin Charlie’s holiday because this happened at the end of it but I felt it was my fault.

His mum is warning others to stay away from black henna tattoos that can leave scars (Picture: Kennedy)

‘Before this happened I’d never heard of it, I don’t want anyone else to go through what he has.

‘To any parents thinking about letting their children get these black henna tattoos I would advise, just say no.

‘Get it up on the internet and show any kids who are asking to have it done plenty of images on Google that would definitely put kids off wanting it.

‘My advice would be to stick to your word and say ‘no’, whether they have a strop or not, it’s just not worth it.’
